what: Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format

title: Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format
Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format
text: x numeric vector values format text digits number digits formatted number

title: Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format
Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format
Format numbers as text with fixed number of decimals — do_format
code: # Simple example: do_format(1.23456) #> [1] "1.23" do_format(c(1, 2), 3) #> [1] "1.000" "2.000"  # Note that round() looses the last digit: do_format(1.20) #> [1] "1.20" round(1.20, digits=2) #> [1] 1.2  # Note that here format() doesn't round correctly: do_format(1.206) #> [1] "1.21" format(1.206, digits=2) #> [1] "1.2"

what: Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
title: Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
code: format_estci(   est,   lwr,   upr,   digits = 2,   ci_sep = " - ",   use_exp = FALSE,   upr_lim = 100 )

title: Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
text: est parameter estimate (numeric scalar) lwr lower limit (numeric scalar) upr upper limit (numeric scalar) digits number digits (numeric scalar) ci_sep CI separator use_exp exp-transform est, lwr, upr upr_lim upper limit printing upr applied use_exp TRUE avoid large numbers.

title: Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
Format estimate with confidence interval — format_estci
code: # Basic usage: format_estci(1.2, 0.8, 1.6) #> [1] "1.20 (0.80 - 1.60)"  # Change CI-separator: format_estci(1.2, 0.8, 1.6, ci_sep="; ") #> [1] "1.20 (0.80; 1.60)"  # Multiple point and interval estimates: format_estci(1:2, 0:1, 2:3) #> [1] "1.00 (0.00 - 2.00)" "2.00 (1.00 - 3.00)"  # Illustrate use of use_exp argument: format_estci(1:2, 0:1, 2:3, use_exp = TRUE) #> [1] "2.72 (1.00 - 7.39)"  "7.39 (2.72 - 20.09)"  # When use_exp = TRUE the upper limit is capped at upr_lim = 100:  format_estci(1:2, 0:1, 4:5, use_exp = TRUE) #> [1] "2.72 (1.00 - 54.60)" "7.39 (2.72 - >100)"

title: Extract coefficient table with CI and p-value from a model fit — get_coeftab
code: get_coeftab(   model,   coef_name,   transform = function(x) x,   ci_method = confint.default,   digits = 3,   digits.p = 3,   ci_sep = " - ",   return = c("est_ci_pval", "all") )

title: Extract coefficient table with CI and p-value from a model fit — get_coeftab
text: model model fit produced lm glm coef_name name coefficient get coefficient table transform optional function (e.g., exp) log-linear model ci_method method obtain confidence intervals digits number digits digits.p number digits p-value ci_sep CI separator return return est, CI p-value ("est_ci_pval") values ("")

title: Extract coefficient table with CI and p-value from a model fit — get_coeftab
Extract coefficient table with CI and p-value from a model fit — get_coeftab
Extract coefficient table with CI and p-value from a model fit — get_coeftab
code: fm <- lm(speed ~ dist, data=cars) summary(fm) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = speed ~ dist, data = cars) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -7.5293 -2.1550  0.3615  2.4377  6.4179  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)  8.28391    0.87438   9.474 1.44e-12 *** #> dist         0.16557    0.01749   9.464 1.49e-12 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 3.156 on 48 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.6511,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.6438  #> F-statistic: 89.57 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 1.49e-12 #>  get_coeftab(fm, "dist") #>                   est_ci pvalue #>                   <char> <char> #> 1: 0.166 (0.130 - 0.201) <0.001  fm <- lm(Ozone ~ Solar.R + Wind + Temp, data=airquality) summary(fm) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = Ozone ~ Solar.R + Wind + Temp, data = airquality) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -40.485 -14.219  -3.551  10.097  95.619  #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) -64.34208   23.05472  -2.791  0.00623 **  #> Solar.R       0.05982    0.02319   2.580  0.01124 *   #> Wind         -3.33359    0.65441  -5.094 1.52e-06 *** #> Temp          1.65209    0.25353   6.516 2.42e-09 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 21.18 on 107 degrees of freedom #>   (42 observations deleted due to missingness) #> Multiple R-squared:  0.6059,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.5948  #> F-statistic: 54.83 on 3 and 107 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 #>  get_coeftab(fm, c("Solar.R", "Wind", "Temp"), ci_sep = "; ") #>                     est_ci pvalue #>                     <char> <char> #> 1:    0.060 (0.014; 0.106)  0.011 #> 2: -3.334 (-4.631; -2.036) <0.001 #> 3:    1.652 (1.149; 2.155) <0.001

what: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
title: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
text: readxl::read_excel slow reading excel files network drives. function fixes copying file temporary file exists local drive quickly read using readxl::read_excel.

title: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
code: quick_read_excel(   path,   sheet = NULL,   range = NULL,   col_names = TRUE,   col_types = NULL,   na = "",   trim_ws = TRUE,   skip = 0,   n_max = Inf,   guess_max = min(1000, n_max),   progress = readxl_progress(),   .name_repair = "unique" )

title: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
text: path Path xls/xlsx file. sheet Sheet read. Either string (name sheet), integer (position sheet). Ignored sheet specified via range. neither argument specifies sheet, defaults first sheet. range cell range read , described cell-specification. Includes typical Excel ranges like "B3:D87", possibly including sheet name like "Budget!B2:G14", . Interpreted strictly, even range forces inclusion leading trailing empty rows columns. Takes precedence skip, n_max sheet. col_names TRUE use first row column names, FALSE get default names, character vector giving name column. user provides col_types vector, col_names can one entry per column, .e. length col_types, one entry per unskipped column. col_types Either NULL guess spreadsheet character vector containing one entry per column options: "skip", "guess", "logical", "numeric", "date", "text" "list". exactly one col_type specified, recycled. content cell skipped column never read column appear data frame output. list cell loads column list length 1 vectors, typed using type guessing logic col_types = NULL, cell--cell basis. na Character vector strings interpret missing values. default, readxl treats blank cells missing data. trim_ws leading trailing whitespace trimmed? skip Minimum number rows skip reading anything, column names data. Leading empty rows automatically skipped, lower bound. Ignored range given. n_max Maximum number data rows read. Trailing empty rows automatically skipped, upper bound number rows returned tibble. Ignored range given. guess_max Maximum number data rows use guessing column types. progress Display progress spinner? default, spinner appears interactive session, outside context knitting document, call likely run several seconds . See readxl_progress() details. .name_repair Handling column names. Passed along tibble::as_tibble(). readxl's default `.name_repair = "unique", ensures column names empty unique.

title: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
text: temporary file made using base::tempfile deleted using base::unlink base::.exit exiting quick_read_excel. arguments taken verbatim readxl::read_excel.

title: Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
Quickly read excel files from network drives — quick_read_excel
code: # Reading an xls-file: path_to_file <- system.file("extdata", "clippy.xls", package = "readxl",                              mustWork = TRUE) quick_read_excel(path_to_file) #> # A tibble: 4 × 2 #>   name                 value               #>   <chr>                <chr>               #> 1 Name                 Clippy              #> 2 Species              paperclip           #> 3 Approx date of death 39083               #> 4 Weight in grams      0.90000000000000002  # Reading an xlsx-file: path_to_file <- system.file("extdata", "clippy.xlsx", package = "readxl",                              mustWork = TRUE) quick_read_excel(path_to_file) #> # A tibble: 4 × 2 #>   name                 value     #>   <chr>                <chr>     #> 1 Name                 Clippy    #> 2 Species              paperclip #> 3 Approx date of death 39083     #> 4 Weight in grams      0.9        # Use readxl::readxl_example() for more excel file examples.  # See readxl::read_excel for more examples

code: head(iris) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa with(iris, show_set(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length)) #>    nA  nB uniqueA uniqueB union intersect AnotB BnotA #> 1 150 150      35      43    54        24    11    19

what: Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
title: Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
text: Add Column Total Row Percentages data.table Tabulation

title: Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
text: tab data.table tabulation; see Examples name_col indicator name column (character numeric) n_col indicator numeric column (character numeric) digits number digits percentages result

title: Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
Add Column Total and Row Percentages to a data.table Tabulation — totpct
code: Iris <- as.data.table(iris)  tab <- Iris[, .N, Species] totpct(tab) #>       Species     N    Pct #>        <char> <num> <char> #> 1:     setosa    50  33.33 #> 2: versicolor    50  33.33 #> 3:  virginica    50  33.33 #> 4:      Total   150 100.00  tab <- Iris[, .(Mean = mean(Sepal.Length), .N), Species] totpct(tab, n_col = 3, digits=1) #>       Species  Mean     N    Pct #>        <char> <num> <num> <char> #> 1:     setosa 5.006    50   33.3 #> 2: versicolor 5.936    50   33.3 #> 3:  virginica 6.588    50   33.3 #> 4:      Total    NA   150  100.0
